column4: I'm having troubles with my internet lately, and I noticed I got an update for dhcp3-client and dhcp3-common on August 16. Is it possible that is related? Problem is: if I try to force the version of dhcp3-common down to the previous one, Synaptic forces me to remove dhcp3-client and ubuntu-minimal. How can I solve this?
What problems exactly?
Random disconnects my sister doesn't have on her Windows laptop
I really suspect those dhcp-* packages to be the culprit, I really want to downgrade them and see if it solves my problem.
You'll probably have to build from source to downgrade
Can you assure me I won't break anything if I remove those packages and install them again later?
Because when packages get upgraded it's because their candidacy has been replaced in the repos. I don't know if old packages remain and you could perhaps get them if you knew the exact package name
I can make no guarantees, no. If it goes wrong you'd probably have to recreate your network interfaces and routes
Synaptic gives me the option to downgrade.
Oh really? I haven't seen that

It would be nice to have a way to downgrade them without uninstalling those other packages, or otherwise just to have an assurance nothing will break when I remove them (and reinstall them later manually)
Install isc-dhcp-client and isc-dhcp-common
They're not in Synaptic. I should mention that I'm still on Maverick, maybe.
isc-dhcp-client and common are the packages, dhcp3-client and common are transitional, they're the same packages though it seems. Exact same version
Ah, perhaps isc-dhcp is only on 11.04 and the transitionals are only on maverick
I see maverick packages for them.
They don't appear in Synaptic
Are you running 64-bit?
Yes, I am
That's explain it, I only see 32-bit packages for it
So, do you think I can uninstall those packages safely for a while?
I can't guarantee internet functionality after reinstalling
Damn. But I think I am going to take the risk, just got another disconnect and I'm really fed up with it
